intro: Gynandriris simulans, commonly known as the false sandmat, is a flowering plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branched stems and small, white or greenish flowers. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and shrublands. Its leaves are finely divided and aromatic, and it produces small, dry fruits that contain seeds. Gynandriris simulans is not widely cultivated but is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
